intro: Sida kohautiana, commonly known as the Mexican mallow, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows as an annual or biennial herb, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, with hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in clusters and are often visited by bees and other pollinators. Sida kohautiana is also known for its fibrous stems, which have been used in traditional crafts and textiles.
